doc.previous: The mirror on the back wall indicates what is not there: the king and queen, and in the words of Harriet Stone, "the generations of spectators who assume the couple's place before the painting".[24] Writing in 1980, the critics Snyder and Cohn observed:
after: In Las Meninas, the king and queen are supposedly "outside" the painting, yet their reflection in the back wall mirror also places them "inside" the pictorial space.[50]

Snyder proposes it is "a mirror of majesty" or an allusion to the mirror for princes. While it is a literal reflection of the king and queen, Snyder writes "it is the image of exemplary monarchs, a reflection of ideal character" [51] Later he focuses his attention on the princess, writing that VelÃ¡zquez's portrait is "the painted equivalent of a manual for the education of the princessâa mirror of the princess" [52]
